  • Ready-made integrations and API-first architecture — integration with government registers is supported, as well as interaction with other systems via APIs.

  • Analytics and service monitoring tools — analytical components enable tracking the status and performance of digital services.

  • Centralized access via a web portal and mobile solutions — users access digital services and documents through a unified web interface and mobile channels.

  • Open-source and vendor independence — the platform is based on open-source software and can be deployed and maintained independently.

docs.title: Liquio user-facing components
docs.text:
Liquio has two primary user-facing components that support different roles: the Admin Panel and the User Workspace.

graph LR
    A[Liquio] --> B[Admin Panel]
    A[Liquio] --> C[User Workspace]

Admin Panel — the Liquio platform user-facing component for development teams. The Admin Panel enables building the logic of services available to users in the User Workspace.

User Workspace — the Liquio platform user-facing component for end users of services built on the platform.

Liquio’s modular architecture enables a seamless workflow: processes configured by low-code developers in the Admin Panel are automatically deployed as services that end users can access through the User Workspace.

What is a process?

Process is an ordered sequence of actions aimed at achieving a specific goal, with clearly defined responsibilities and expected outcomes. In the Liquio Admin Panel, a process is represented as a BPMN diagram that visualizes steps, decisions, parallel actions, and participant roles.

How to create a process?

docs.title: How to monitor a process?
docs.text:
What are logs?

BPMN logs display the lifecycle of processes: from schema parsing by the service and message processing to task execution and user interaction. Logs are an important tool for monitoring, analyzing, and optimizing the work of each service, ensuring transparency and control at every stage of the process.

Process monitoring is performed on the Journals/Process logs tab of the Admin Panel.

docs.title: Logs
docs.text:
Steps:

To view process logs, follow these steps:

  1. Go to the Journals/Process logs section in the Admin Panel.

  2. Find and click on the process for which you need to view logs.

  3. Review the displayed logs of the selected process.

docs.title: Filters for searching process logs
docs.text:
The Admin Panel provides the following set of filters for searching process logs:

  • Errors — search for processes taking into account the presence of blocking errors:

    • No errors — processes without blocking errors are displayed.

    • Only with errors — processes with blocking errors are displayed.

  • Process name — filter for searching processes by name.

  • Process number — filter for searching processes by application number generated according to the number template.

  • User — search by Full name, ITN or user identifier.

  • Status — filter by current process status:

    • 🟡 In progress — processes that are currently in doing status (marked in yellow).

    • 🟢 Completed — processes that are currently in done status (marked in green).

    • 🔴 Rejected — processes that are currently in rejected status (marked in red).

    • ⚪ Draft — processes in which the user has not yet submitted an application.

    • ⚫ All except drafts — processes that are in one of the statuses doing, done or rejected.

  • Creation date — filter for searching processes by creation date.

  • Update date — filter for searching processes by the date of the last update on the process:

    • if it is a draft, the update date will be the date when the user last made changes to the form;

    • if it is not a draft, the update date will be the date of creation/update of the last business process element.

Combining filters

All available filters can be combined with each other.

For example, to find all processes with the name Test process that ended with errors in the last day, you need to execute a query with the following filters: Errors: Only with errors, Process name: Test process

docs.title: How to save data to a registry?
docs.text:
Prerequisites

To save process data to a registry, you need to add an Event element with the Request type to the diagram.

For a description of process elements and working with the editor, see the page How to configure a process?

docs.title: Saving to a registry
docs.text:
To configure saving to a registry, perform the following actions:

1) In the process diagram, select the Event element with the Request type.

2) In the settings panel that opens on the right, go to the Event diagram tab.

3) A window opens for entering code in JSON format.

4) Add code with special syntax. List of supported parameters.

5) Save the written code by clicking the Save icon.

docs.title: Supported parameters
docs.text:
1) saveToRegisters — required parameter that accepts a function string or an object with mapping data:

  • variant: function string — describes a JavaScript string function that takes one argument — documents (array of process documents). The result of processing will be a data object for saving to the registry, or an object with mapping data to the registry key schema. The function result contains the following parameters:

    • registerId — required parameter to determine which registry the data will be saved to by its identifier. Type — number;
    • keyId — required parameter to determine which registry key the data will be saved to by its identifier. Type — number;
    • allowTokens — optional parameter that accepts a list of unit tokens to grant access to this record in the registry. Type — array;

    Please note!

    If a unit has permission to access the registry, but it is not in this list, the records may be inaccessible.

    If this parameter is not set, the records will be accessible to all units that have access in the registry key settings.

    • data — required parameter, which is an object with a list of field data to save them to the registry. Type - object.
    Example of using saveToRegisters as a function string 

    {
        "saveToRegisters": "
            (documents) => {
                const document = documents.find((item => item.documentTemplateId === 100));
                const country = document?.data?.countryInfo;
                const {
                    name,
                    code,
                    timeZone
                } = country;
                return {
                    registerId: 123,
                    keyId: 1231,
                    allowTokens: ['token1', 'token2', 'tokenN'],
                    data: {
                        name,
                        code: String(code),
                        timeZone
                    }
                }
            };
        "
    }

  • variant: object with mapping data — the function result contains the following parameters:

    • parameters registerId, keyId, allowTokens — similar to the variant when the parameter accepts a function string;

    Info

    The allowTokens parameter can also accept a function string that takes two arguments: documents (array of documents of the current process) and events (array of events of the current process), the result of which should be an array of unit tokens;

    • person — optional parameter that has type object or is a function string that takes two arguments documents (array of documents of the current process) and events (array of events of the current process) with user data responsible for creating the record. Record format: {id, name}, where: id — identifier of the user who made the record, name — full name of the user who made the record. The result of execution should be an object with filled parameters {id, name} respectively. The parameter is necessary in cases when it is needed to record who exactly made the record to the registry. It is recorded in the change history, since by default it is system.

    • map — required parameter, which is a mapping object, the parameters of which have the same names as the list in the registry key schema. Type — object. Values have the following recording variants:

      • string with path to the required document value by process — documents.<document-template-id>.<inner-document-path>, where:

        • documents — parameter with the value of the array of process documents;

        • document-template-id — identifier of the process number documentTemplateId from which data needs to be obtained. The value can be found in Process logs;

        • inner-document-path — path to parameters that are stored in the data. The path can be determined by the execution results in Process logs.

      • function string that takes two arguments: documents (array of documents by process) and events (array of events by process), and returns the required parameter value.

    Example of using saveToRegisters as an object with mapping data 
    {
    "saveToRegisters": {
        "registerId": 123,
        "keyId": 1234,
        "person": "(documents, events) => { const documentData = documents.find(item => item.documentTemplateId === 100).data; return { id: documentData?.calculated?.userId, name: documentData?.calculated?.userName }; }",
        "allowTokens": [10001],
        "map": {
            "name": "documents.100.data.countryInfo.name",
            "code": "(documents, events) => { const code = documents.find(item => item.documentTemplateId === 100).data?.countryInfo?.code; return String(code); }",
            "timeZone": "documents.100.data.countryInfo.timeZone"
        }
    }
}

    2) accessInfo — optional parameter, which is a function that takes two arguments documents (array of documents of the current process) and events (array of events of the current process).

    Must be set if for the corresponding registry it is necessary to record data (full name, user identifier) in the change history (creation, deletion, editing of records) in the User Workspace.

    The Liquio Event service additionally records workflowId (identifier of the current process) and requestAt (date and time of the action relative to the registry) when executing the function.

    Example code using the accessInfo parameter 
    {
    "saveToRegisters": {
        "registerId": 123,
        "keyId": 1234,
        "person": "(documents, events) => { const documentData = documents.find(item => item.documentTemplateId === 100).data; return { id: documentData?.calculated?.userId, name: documentData?.calculated?.userName }; }",
        "allowTokens": [10001],
        "map": {
            "name": "documents.100.data.countryInfo.name",
            "code": "(documents, events) => { const code = documents.find(item => item.documentTemplateId === 100).data?.countryInfo?.code; return String(code); }",
            "timeZone": "documents.100.data.countryInfo.timeZone"
        }
    },
    "accessInfo": "(documents, events) => { const documentData = documents.find(item => item.documentTemplateId === 100).data; return { userId: documentData?.calculated?.userId, userName: documentData?.calculated?.userName }; }"
}

docs.title: How to authorize?
docs.text:
Tip

Users can authorize in the Admin Panel or in the User Workspace. The authorization process is provided by a separate Liquio component, so it is unified. User access to platform's user-facing components is determined by the role assigned by the administrator.

docs.title: Authorization methods
docs.text:
To log in to the platform, you need to complete authentication - identity verification. The platform offers several convenient authentication methods using:

  • Bank ID;
  • file key;
  • hardware key;
  • login and password (for administrative panel only).

docs.title: Authorization with Bank ID
docs.text:
What is Bank ID

Bank ID is an electronic system for user identification and authentication that allows you to verify identity online using banking credentials.

Steps:

  1. On the authentication page, click Log in.

  2. Click Bank ID NBU.

  3. Select your bank from the list.

  4. Log in using your bank credentials.

  5. Click the Continue button.

docs.title: Authorization with file key
docs.text:
What is a file key

File key is a protected file with a personal electronic signature (QES) used to verify identity and sign electronic documents. It requires a password to be entered each time it is used. It usually has one of the following extensions: .dat, .pfx, .zs2, .jks

Steps:

  1. On the authentication page, click File key.

  2. Drag the key file to the upload field or click the Select key on your device link and specify the path to the key file saved on your PC.

  3. Select an electronic service provider from the list or leave the value Determine automatically.

  4. Enter the key password.

docs.title: Authorization with hardware key
docs.text:
What is a hardware key

Hardware key is a physical device (USB token, smart card) for storing electronic signatures and secure user authentication in digital services.

Steps:

  1. On the authentication page, click Hardware key.

  2. Connect the hardware key to your PC. If necessary, click the Refresh button.

  3. In the Qualified trust service provider field, select an electronic service provider from the list or leave the value Determine automatically.

  4. In the Password field, enter the key password.

  5. If necessary, click the Add certificate button.

Warning

If necessary, install additional packages for the signature web library. To do this, download the EUSignWebInstall file from the link Signature web library installation package. Additionally, refer to the user manual.

docs.title: Authorization with login and password
docs.text:
Steps:

  1. On the authentication page, click Login and password.

  2. Fill in the Email and Password fields.

  3. Click the Log in button.
